dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, it's like we've been trying to fix a car without really understanding how the engine works.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, it's like we've been trying to fix a car without really understanding how the engine works.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's exactly what Dr. Allison and his team realized with that immune system brake—they figured out if you release it, the body can attack cancer on its own.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's exactly what Dr. Allison and his team realized with that immune system brake-they figured out if you release it, the body can attack cancer on its own.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For years, Allison and his colleagues studied a protein that serves as a brake on the immune system. They recognized that releasing this brake could unleash the immune system to attack and destroy tumors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then Dr. Honjo found another protein doing something similar. It's wild how these discoveries are already saving lives, but, uh, it's still so hit-or-miss for patients.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then Dr. Honjo found another protein doing something similar. It's wild how these discoveries are already saving lives, but, uh, it's still so hit-or-miss for patients.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Independently, Honjo and colleagues identified another protein that performed a similar function. For some patients with some cancers, immunotherapy has been revolutionary, enabling people who had been on the verge of death to live healthy lives with no detectable traces of the disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. I mean, some people have these miraculous recoveries, but so many others just don't respond at all. We're really just scratching the surface here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. I mean, some people have these miraculous recoveries, but so many others just don't respond at all. We're really just scratching the surface here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For some patients with some cancers, immunotherapy has been revolutionary, enabling people who had been on the verge of death to live healthy lives with no detectable traces of the disease. Yet the immunotherapy revolution is still in its infancy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the article mentions HIV vaccine research too—decades of work, and it's still elusive. That shows how little we actually know about immune response.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the article mentions H I V vaccine research too-decades of work, and it's still elusive. That shows how little we actually know about immune response.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I have seen this firsthand, through decades of work trying to develop a vaccine for HIV/AIDS, a goal that has so far proved elusive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's humbling. But the idea of using AI and machine learning to decode the immune system… that feels like a game-changer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's humbling. But the idea of using A I and machine learning to decode the immune system... that feels like a game-changer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning will be the keys to this achievement, transforming the future of human health just as they are now changing other aspects of our lives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The scale is insane—billions of times larger than the human genome. We're gonna need serious computing power just to process all that data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. The scale is insane-billions of times larger than the human genome. We're gonna need serious computing power just to process all that data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is billions of times larger than the human genome, and processing such a huge amount of information requires significant data-science capabilities and frontier supercomputing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're already trying it out, like, the Human Vaccines Project with places like J. Craig Venter Institute. They're gathering millions of data points per person instead of just a little from thousands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're already trying it out, like, the Human Vaccines Project with places like J. Craig Venter Institute. They're gathering millions of data points per person instead of just a little from thousands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In early work being conducted through the Human Vaccines Project, scientists at the J. Craig Venter Institute, the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and the University of British Columbia are using this approach to identify baseline biomarkers in individuals that predict immune responses to vaccines. With the remarkable new genomics and molecular biology tools now available, researchers can collect millions of data points on a single individual.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a huge shift in how we do research. Fewer people, way more depth. AI can find patterns we'd never spot on our own.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a huge shift in how we do research. Fewer people, way more depth. A I can find patterns we'd never spot on our own.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is leading us to a new model: fewer people, much more data. By merging AI and machine learning to analyze these individual data sets, we can better understand the molecular-level dynamics of the human immune system and start mapping its governing rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Imagine an actual atlas of the immune system—that's the moonshot goal here. It could revolutionize not just cancer, but Alzheimer's, malaria, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Imagine an actual atlas of the immune system-that's the moonshot goal here. It could revolutionize not just cancer, but Alzheimer's, malaria, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Studies like these are starting to yield an unprecedented amount of data that ultimately will enable the creation of the first-ever atlas of the human immune system. Decoding it should be central to our efforts to understand and fight illness, whether non-communicable diseases such as cancer, diabetes, and Alzheimers, or infectious ones such as tuberculosis, malaria, and Ebola.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the end vision is pretty breathtaking: lifetime vaccines with one shot, immunotherapy for all cancers… it almost sounds like science fiction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the end vision is pretty breathtaking: lifetime vaccines with one shot, immunotherapy for all cancers... it almost sounds like science fiction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I envision a world where scientists can rapidly develop new ways to fight disease; where vaccines provide lifetime protection for everyone, with a single immunization; where immunotherapy works for all cancers; and where Alzheimers is preventable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But it's within reach if we commit to it like the Human Genome Project. We've got the tools now; we just need the will.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's within reach if we commit to it like the Human Genome Project. We've got the tools now; we just need the will.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We need new and creative ways of approaching the challenge across multiple disciplines a coordinated effort on the moonshot scale of the Human Genome Project. The good news is that such an undertaking is now possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, merging creativity with AI… that's how we crack this code. What a time to be alive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, merging creativity with A I... that's how we crack this code. What a time to be alive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To make this future a reality, we must merge creativity with continued advances in AI to crack the code of the human immune system.
